message: Hey there Go Off! Community
hello! looking forward to the chat
to open today's discussion with a basic question - what is your favorite Disney movie and why
As a kid, my favorite was Hercules because I loved the music
I actually just watched hercules for the first time this past weekend, and I loved the music!
Yeah the best Disney music!
I'd have to say my favorite Disney movie is probably lilo and stitch or the Monsters Inc movies
yeah those were fun to watch as a kid too
to me, what's most interesting about Disney is the fact that their content is way more than just kids movies we grew up watching
Right! I don't have disney+, but I was looking through my friend's account and forgot how much stuff they own and create
Yeah! right now Disney owns just under 40% of American media and production
That's crazy, and it sounds like they're going to keep pushing for more of their content to be released on Disney+ right?
I wonder how that will impact Netflix or Prime
yeah, that's exactly what the article touches on
Personally, I think they are trying to compete with the internet exclusives on Netflix or prime
Most of Disney's stuff is released on mainstream theaters and television networks
but the market is leaning further and further towards preferring the exclusivity of streaming platform originals
Even before COVID, I think the last movie I saw in theaters was LaLa Land? So yeah, I can see how streaming is really taking over the market
theaters were becoming more of a novelty and less a viewing necessity before covid. Now all the content that's been released over the last six months has been online
and they actually didn't lose as much money as anticipated by doing that
interesting. do you know of any media companies that aren't adapting well to the shift toward streaming?
It's honestly something I didn't consider looking into for this conversation. But it would have been interesting to compare why they fail or survive in the age of "stream-mageddon"
what interested me more is why a media company as Big as Disney would want to put all of their content online
I feel like one of the main reasons they're doing it (besides money) is because it feels like the "right thing to do" at this time
every company, not just media ones, are really pushing for that online presence, and it seems like Disney fears being unrelatable or disconnected from that audience
That's very true, in the past Disney has failed to keep up with media trends and at one point was a very conservative company
so I think a huge part of this is a bid for a positive public opinion
as a way to hold peoples interest
because of the endless options for streaming and media online

I just watched a 40 minute video of the try guys eating everything at Jack in the Box. They aren't in the same league as Disney, but Disney knows they are competing with thousands of versions of the try guys for our attention
it makes sense to take their media where our attention already is.
yeah that's a really good point. do you think the actual content itself will shift more too? like to fit shorter form youtube content or short tv series?

I think they will always put out high quality content, like the Mandalorian or Toy Story. But it wouldn't surprise me if they also started a short form or low budget arm of production specifically for youtube audiences
nickelodeon did it with Awesomeness TV and they have been very successful
not only does Disney have to keep up with the trends, but I forget that much of their revenue also comes from theme parks and cruise ships, which have all been shut down
Yeah another reason for this dramatic restructuring could be to recoup some of the losses from their theme park and vacation
arms
I think they were trying to make up for some loss of audience in recent years with all of the live-action remakes of classic films
Hi. I'm Ashley I am here
the current model wasn't exactly covid proof
hey Ashley! welcome to the convo
Hi Ashley!
So I want to continue the convo by asking
do you think that Disney's streaming forward restructuring is viable in the long term
I honestly think it is considering how popular Netflix, YouTube premium and other channels are
Thats very true
I think it will come down to almost a competition like CBS, ABC, and NBC have but with Netflix and Disney+ and maybe Prime or Youtube?
I'm not sure if it's viable long term, but for now, the streaming is definitely helping them out
I know a lot of college kids are really into Disney+ even though most of the movies aren't technically made for our age group
I agree, it works well now. Their most recognizable and most popular properties are the blockbuster movies that they release in theaters
and the mulan release they did only on Disney plus flopped majorly
I think they should be smarter about it than by putting all of their content online
I think Disney movies really hold a special place in everyone's heart and I think now with COVID-19 people want to be sentimental
thats a really good point. A lot of people got Disney plus over the quarantine to rewatch their favorite movies
But will this model work for new content as well?
and for content that isnt animated, like sports
I think we are entering a new stage in our lives where the newest consumer doesn't always stay in one place and is on the move
so yes

that's a great question. I think that even though Disney can put out good content on streaming services, it's hard to replace the experience of going to see a movie or watching a sports game on live tv
They have a controlling stake in Hulu and they own ESPN which have live sports. But putting it online completely changes how people experience the content, to begin with.
yeah absolutely
it will be interesting to see how media companies try to emulate that movie-going experience with streaming services
I think there will be a shift to a more community-oriented experience
like a way to engage audiences while they stream
make them feel like the are out watching a movie
yeah I think whatever company does the best at that will have the most longevity in streaming
its a bit like a contest
and its interesting to see how each of them interpret what they think audiences want
I think people during these times really want to feel connected to others
yeah Netflix parties does a good job at encouraging that
but i also just realized it wasn't started by Netflix, so maybe it will be up to individual companies to foster that connection
Netflix was my go-to for connecting with people during quaramtine
which was a huge win for them
because that was the experience many audiences had
we are coming up on the end of our convo
to wrap what does everyone see the future of movie-going to be?
I'm selfishly hoping that after these next couple of years of people continuing to stream and stay in more, there will be a boom in theaters and movie-going!
will theaters ever come back? or will streaming take over?
I'm not sure if theaters will come back in the same form that they existed pre-COVID 19.
will theaters come back ? or will we stream everything?
I like to think that there will be a wave of more theater-going when people want to reminisce and go back to the "good old days" of watching movies hahaha
I think people are pretty stubborn, so the tradition will persist. Unless, of course, the pandemic goes on longer than any of us would like it to!
okay well this is about the end of our convo! have a great night everybody
good night!
thank you for hosting and thanks everyone it was nice chatting with you!
